69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (07:20): writing author and UA criteria for DOM APIs poses an interesting problem
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (07:20): i want it to be possible to hide the UA requirements
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (07:20): but that means that DOM requirements end up reading as:
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (07:21): The /foo/ attribute returns the foo. On getting, the user agent must return the foo.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (07:21): which sounds stupid.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (07:21): I wonder how to address this problem.
6d05f0c2942adc25946a4b02b37ffa00 (07:42): that's not an author criteria though
6d05f0c2942adc25946a4b02b37ffa00 (07:43): that's just explaining how it works
6d05f0c2942adc25946a4b02b37ffa00 (07:53): hmm, cool, HTML5 doesn't create CDATASection nodes for text/html
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (07:55): well we need something that tells the author how it works, i mean, i can't just remove the UA criteria leaving just the IDL
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (07:55): or can we?
6d05f0c2942adc25946a4b02b37ffa00 (07:59): no, but an introduction section that explains all methods should suffice
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (08:00): If the UA criteria are accurately expressed by the IDL, seems like the prose could actually be removed.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (08:00): nm, 6d05f0c2942adc25946a4b02b37ffa00 just clarified
6d05f0c2942adc25946a4b02b37ffa00 (08:01): it might be a lot of work, but both an author and UA section for each IDL would be ideal, I think
6d05f0c2942adc25946a4b02b37ffa00 (08:01): with the same pedantic detail as writing versus parsing HTML
